pred:
The discussion about the working of the remote control revolved around several key points:


- The need for a simple, easy-to-use remote control that is targeted at young people. The remote control should be simple and easy to use, with few buttons and a backlight.


- The need for a power button and volume control. The power button should be automatic and the volume control should be easy to use.

- The need for a channel selection button that is often used and relevant. The channel selection button should be very often used and relevant.

- The need for a power button that is stress-free. The power button should not be repetitive.

- The need for a speech recognition feature. Speech recognition should be considered for the remote control.

- The need for a gesture control. Gesture control should be considered for the remote control.

- The need for a universal remote control. The remote control should be universal and work with multiple devices.
- The need for a price of around €5-10. The remote control should be affordable.

- The need for a personalized remote. Each user should have their own remote with their own settings.

- The need for a remote control that is targeted at me. The remote control should be targeted at a specific user.
- The need for a remote control that is personalized. The remote control should be personalized for each user.
- The need for a remote control that is cheap. The remote control should be affordable.
- The need for a remote control that is universal. The remote control should be universal and work with multiple devices.
- The need for a remote control that is simple. The remote control should be simple and easy to use.
- The need for a remote control that is targeted at young people. The remote control should be simple and easy to use, with few buttons and a backlight.
- The need for a power button and volume control. The power button should be automatic and the volume control should be easy to use.
- The need for a channel selection button that is often used and relevant. The channel selection button should be very often used and relevant.
- The need for a power button that is stress-free. The power button should not be repetitive.
- The need for a speech recognition feature. Speech recognition should be considered for the remote control.
answers: The industrial designer described the product as a portable device with some energy source, an interface which included some pressing buttons and keys, a processor, some infrared source which could send the information to the main device, and different encryption codes for different TVs. Since the Marketing and the user interface designer mentioned speech recognition, the industrial designer also took that into account. All these components would cost 5 Euros or even less than that. As for gesture recognition and automatic power control, the group gave them up due to price issues. At the end of the meeting, the group also talked about how to enable the users to find the controller.

pred: The group talked about the touch screen under the limitation of the budget by discussing the cost to produce it. Specifically, they estimated that it would cost $175 per remote to add the touch screen feature to the existing remote control design. This was based on the estimate of $175 per remote to produce the existing remote design, and $25 margin per remote to sell at $30 profit margin. So the total cost would be $250 per remote with the touch screen feature.
answers: The group found that if they would use the touch screen as well as the voice recognition technique, the cost would up to 17 euros. On the other hand, in order to guarantee the one hundred percent profit, the price would be more than 30, which would risk losing potential consumers. Provided that they would control the cost within 12.5 euros, they would have to cut off some functions, for example, voice recognition. It was really hard to balance between the popular tastes, the cost and the quality.

pred: The general discussion was about the recognition results from the first meeting.
answers: The group discussed recognition results generated for 20 minutes of close-talking microphone data. Recognition performance was very good, indicating promising results for forced alignment procedures and the ability to analyze other important signal information, e.g. prosody and overlapping speech. It was decided that close-talking data should be downsampled and fed to the SRI recognizer to compare recognition performance, and that data from the far-field microphones should be tested on the recognizer as soon as possible. The group also discussed recording setup and equipment issues.

pred: Marketing thought that the remote control should have no buttons on it to do that, since most people do not use them 90% of the time.
answers: The Marketing thought buttons can be omitted, just like cell phones, because many of the functions of buttons, such as the TV button, are generally not used. But they can set up a menu-style button if they really need to.

pred: The professor thought that clustering could be a good way to get binary labels for the data.
answers: The professor was not too excited about clustering. He thought that the team could identify the bands that were the most promising and weigh them more highly in the model. As it stood, the model was using all bands with equal strength.

pred: Grad F said he would start with a proposal, give it to people ahead of time, and then ask questions.
answers: Grad F explained that he was focusing on writing his proposal for his qualification exams, which was on the 25th of July. He had to write a paper and pass it around before that date.

pred: The group discussed speech recognition as a possible feature to include in the remote control. Marketing suggested it could be added to the remote control. Industrial Designer agreed it was a good idea, but they did not have time to discuss it in detail. Project Manager thought it was expensive and would not be included. User Interface said it was not necessary.
answers: Since the marketing and the user interface designer mentioned speech recognition in their previous presentations, the industrial designer suggested putting a simple speech recogniser on the digital signal processing chip and training the speech recogniser for particular users. However, the user interface designer concerned that it would be too complex. Then the industrial designer argued that even some simple mobile devices could have these voice dialers so it wouldn't be so sophisticated, and the marketing also said the product would be good to sell with the speech recogniser.

pred:
The two lessons that can be learned from early implementer areas are:


1. The burden of administration on each local authority and each pilot area, to administer a scheme where we are asking parents to provide eligibility documents to prove their eligibility, to adjustments as it goes forward based on their changing work patterns is very bureaucratic.


2. The biggest challenge is communication with parents, who are outside the areas entirely saying "Why haven't we got this yet?" Can we please get into it", which is encouraging. But the other thing is people within pilot areas where it doesn't extend to the whole authority, saying "Well, hold on now, we think we qualify for something under universal care, we think we qualify for something on tax credits."
answers: Huw Irranca-Davies mentioned two things that their teams learned from early implementer areas. The first one was how to deal with bureaucracy and the second was about communication with both parents and pilot authorities.

pred:
The discussion about trend watching and appearance focused on the following key points:


- The trends in appearance and design are similar across many products, such as clothing, furniture, and remote controls. 

- The trends are driven by people watching what others are using and creating, not just following them. 
- The trends are inspired by what is new and novel, not just copying what is already out there.

- The trends travel from city to city, so they are not specific to remote controls.
- The trends are about fruit and vegetable shapes and spongy materials.
- The trends are about being fancy, technologically innovative, and easy to use.
- The trends are about being useful as a remote control, but not as important as a remote control.

- The trends are about being fancy, not useful as a remote control.

- The trends are about fruit and vegetable shapes and spongy materials.
- The trends are about being fancy, technologically innovative, easy to use, and useful as a remote control.
- The trends are about being fancy, technologically innovative, easy to use, and useful as a remote control.
answers: The marketing put forward three noteworthy aspects in trends. First and foremost, people loved fancy things that they could be identified with. The second point was that as a remote control it had to be technologically innovative. Thirdly, being easy to use was also necessary. From a broader perspective, fruit and vegetables were in fashion this year and being spongy was also popular. Thus, contrary to the industrial designer, the marketing thought rubber was more feasible in terms of sponginess. The group agreed that the product should resemble fruit and vegetable in shape and colour but the specific design was not decided.

pred: The professor thought that echoes and reverberation could be causing problems in the speech recognition system. He mentioned that the Aurora baseline system was not as good on meeting digits as it was on TI digits, and that the SRI system was better on meeting digits than the Aurora baseline system. He also thought that the SRI system had more complex acoustic models than the Aurora system.
answers: The professor thought it was possible to reduce the effects of reverberation by removing the low-energy segments. He thought a VAD-like approach would work. This would make it so that the model was more likely to keep an echo than throw out speech.

answers: Although there were no exact figures,they had seen over recent years that they were only recruiting to about 65 percent of targets. It was partially due to the financial incentives, but that was not all of the problems. Because this issue was not only in Wales, but a common issue in all over the world. For example, in England, despite higher financial incentives to join ITE courses, people still were not getting onto those courses. To solve this problem, they had taken several steps including making sure their ITE provision was world class, embarking on the first national ITE recruitment marketing exercise, etc. In this process, Llyr Gruffydd had a doubt that the level of ambition did not reflect the level of action that was needed actually. Kirsty Williams responded that different statistics told different stories. They obviously understood there were many steps they had to take, but they were trying instead of just sitting back and waiting.

answers: Efforts by speaker mn005 are in progress to detect overlapping speech. For a single transcribed meeting, speaker mn005 reported approximately 300 cases of overlap. Future work will involve manually deriving time marks from sections of overlapping speech for the same meeting, and then experimenting with different measures, e.g. energy increase, to determine a set of acoustically salient features for identifying speaker overlap.

pred: The discussion about project finance focused on evaluating the costs of the prototype and production of the remote control. The team decided to use an Excel spreadsheet to help calculate the production costs. They estimated that the prototype would cost £1250000,000, and the production would cost £1000,00000. They had £15,000000 left in the budget for other expenses. They decided to keep the features, including voice recognition, LCD display, and speaker, and scroll wheel. They decided to remove the locator, which was the most expensive feature. The final cost was £125,00000 over budget. They decided to keep the scroll wheel and buttons on the side instead of scrolling. They decided to remove the scroll wheel and buttons on the side. The final cost was £10,00000 over budget.
answers: The production cost was 12.5 Euros. So, the group decided to have one simple battery, no kinetic energy, no solar, one advanced chip on print, one sample speaker, one single-curved surface which can be folded, push-buttons, the scroll wheel, the LCD display. And they decided to give up the sample sensor as well as the locator.

pred: Industrial Design agreed with Marketing when discussing their presentations on the appearance because they both felt that the voice recognition technology was simpler to implement and already had the necessary technology in-house. They both felt that the voice recognition would be easier to implement and cheaper to produce than the touch screen.
answers: While discussing their presentations on the appearance design, both the Industrial Design and the Marketing put forward to use rubber as the material rather than other things like wood. The Industrial Design agreed to choose rubber because it can stand beat, drop and extrusion.

pred: The meeting was about designing a new remote control for a TV. The team discussed the design, features, materials, cost, and evaluation criteria. They decided to make a prototype and evaluate it. The team agreed on a fancy design with two buttons and a dial. The prototype was made and evaluated. The team decided to make it in titanium. The meeting finished with a celebration.
answers: It was the last meeting of the group and focused on detail design. First, the user interface designer displayed the appearance and the texture of the product with a working prototype. After that, the industrial designer gave some technical specifications on the product. In the product evaluation that included several criteria, the controller got an average score of two point one seven, which implied it was good. When it came to the quotation of product components, the original one was seventeen dot eight dollars, which was apparently over budget. answers: The group discussed recognition results generated for 20 minutes of close-talking microphone data. Recognition performance was very good, indicating promising results for forced alignment procedures and the ability to analyze other important signal information, e.g. prosody and overlapping speech. It was decided that close-talking data should be downsampled and fed to the SRI recognizer to compare recognition performance, and that data from the far-field microphones should be tested on the recognizer as soon as possible.

pred: The allocation for 2019-20 specifically contributes to educational research by funding the WISERD Education project, which is a research collaboration between a number of Welsh universities looking at educational issues and providing additional funding to value to the Welsh Government's evaluation of the progress of pioneer schools in developing the three-to-five curriculum in Wales.

answers: The group briefly talked about their agreements of the past meetings. They were all concerned with the interchangeable user interfaces and they agreed to make it more natural-looking and multi-faces. The Industrial Design then mentioned the issue of the material. They decided to use a rubber coat in case the remote control would be damaged when being dropped occasionally. After most details were checked, the Project Manager turned to the budget problem. It is quite essential for them to be both environmentally friendly and economic.

pred: The group thought that disposable income was higher for people in the 15-25 age bracket compared to those in the 30-35 age bracket. Specifically, the survey showed that 76.3% of 15-25 year olds would pay more for a more stylish remote control compared to 15.2% of 30-35 year olds.
answers: Industrial Designer suggested they should also look up popularity among the 25 to 35 years old age group if they looked into a stylish design. Marketing said it was 70% popular among this age group and thought this age group didn't have much economic burden so the remote price should not be unaffordable. User Interface supplemented that their remote might not function with the old TV. Therefore, the group decided to include both 15 to 25 and 25 to 35 years old age group into consideration.

pred: The conclusion of the discussion about Marketing strategy when discussing group's plan of their marketing strategy is that they should make a universal remote control that works with all brands and things.
answers: The team decided that the remote had to be compatible with most of the world's TVS, or at least the ones they made. And the buttons must be internationally recognized.They also thought that the function of the remote control was to change the state of the TV and this could be realized by pressing the button.

pred: The marketing thought they should aim at young people because young people are the early adopters of new devices and are more likely to be interested in a new device.
answers: Because in general the early adopters of a new device were young people and teletext was used less among the young than the elderly. Plus, the young found it very relevant to have speech recognition in their remote control so that they could just tell the controller what they wanted instead of zapping.
